Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will publish the report of the Committee which was set up to deal with the question of access to third level education.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I assume that what the Deputy has in mind is the report of a task force set up in my Department to review admissions procedures to third level education. As appropriate consultations and follow-up action on the recommendations of the task force have been set in train, and it is my intention to make available to the public the necessary data in the report.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she has considered the possibility of introducing in-service training courses for members of boards of management of national schools or of assisting the relevant trustees in organising such courses.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The management of national schools is one of the issues that fall within the remit of the Primary Education Review Body. Although I would not wish to pre-empt the findings of the review body in this regard, personally I would be in favour of such in-service training courses.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Capitation Grants.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will outline the present basis on which capitation grants are paid to schools with particular reference to the requirement of raising a local contribution; if the local contribution is differentiated between different areas in accordance with the different revenue raising potential of individual areas.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The handbook “Boards of Management of National Schools — Constitution of Boards and Rules of Procedure” states:

A local contribution towards operating-expenses, equivalent to at least 25 per cent of the State capitation grant, must be lodged each year in a bank account in the name of the school, save that the Minister may accept a smaller local contribution in the case of certain categories of school, e.g. special schools. The sum required to meet the local contribution shall be provided by the parish community or other appropriate analogous community or body from general funds at the disposal of such community or body and there shall be no levy on parents of children attending the school.

MainHeading.P: The same maximum local contribution applies to all national schools.

Per capita grants are paid to secondary schools in the free post-primary education scheme at the rate of £140 per eligible pupil per annum. There is no requirement in the scheme that a local contribution should be raised.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if her attention has been drawn to a Government plan in Britain to ensure that: (1) every year 10 per cent of all teachers be given the opportunity to gain some business experience, (2) that all pupils should have at least two weeks suitable work experience before leaving school and (3) that every trainee teacher should have an appreciation of the needs of employers; and if she has similar proposals in each of these three areas.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The position in regard to work experience for pupils is that all vocational preparation and training programmes include work experience. It may also be a feature of the transition year option in some schools and in addition many schools arrange on an informal basis for visits to local businesses. I have no plans to introduce a requirement in this area in school programmes generally or to introduce a scheme of business experience for teachers.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Attainment Targets in Education.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if her attention has been drawn to the fact that the Department of Education in Britain is introducing attainment targets and assessment arrangements, allowing for variations in ability at the key ages of 7, 11, 14 and 16; if she has any proposals to measure progress in Irish education on a similar or comparable basis; and if she is satisfied that children in need of remedial help are objectively identified in Ireland at a sufficiently early age.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The arrangements being made in Great Britain for assessment at various ages have been noted. The question of assessment in our primary schools is one of the issues currently under discussion by the Primary Curriculum Review Body.
The guidelines on remedial education issued to all primary schools this year stress the need for early identification of learning problems.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Qualification for Higher Education Grant.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will remove the anomaly whereby the minimum academic qualification for a higher education grant is four honours, even when this is higher than the entrance requirement for some faculties in some colleges.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: As I have previously indicated, I am examining the terms of the higher education grants scheme including the requirements related to the minimum academic requirement of four honours rule.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the action which is being taken on foot of the Programme for Action in Education (details supplied) in relation to the provision in order that at any stage in life, after the period of compulsory school attendance, people could sit for any of the national examinations; the provision which exists at present in regard to this matter; the provision which existed some years ago; and if any change is envisaged.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: Under existing provisions, special admission to the leaving certificate examination is available to anyone who has attained the age of 17. For admission to both intermediate and day vocational (group) examinations, candidates must have completed an approved course as recognised pupils. Under these provisions, mature students may sit for the intermediate certificate examination provided they have followed a course approved by the Department. There are no admission requirements for the technical schools examinations.

The Vocational Training Opportunity Scheme (with 60 participants) has been operating in Tallaght and in Limerick since 1985, on a pilot basis. It is now being extended to ten additional centres providing places for 200 people in the main centres of unemployment.
It is planned to extend the scheme progressively, with further groups starting in January 1990. It is envisaged that over 600 places will be provided during 1990.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - In-Service Teacher Training.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if her attention has been drawn to the fact that data processing is the top priority area for the in-service training of 620,000 primary and secondary teachers in France; if she has examined this French initiative; and if she will outline her policy in regard to in-service training for Irish teachers in this matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if her attention has been drawn to the fact that in Sweden every teacher is required to take part in in-service study days each year; and if she has considered a similar requirement here.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 345 and 346 together.
My Department is generally aware of developments in other countries and carries out reviews of such developments in the light of relevance to Irish educational requirements.

MainHeading.P: In accordance with this policy, in-service courses have been provided for post-primary teachers in recent years which covered the complete range of topics comprehended by Computer Studies including data processing. This year alone at least ten courses in the area of computers have been held by my Department.

The introduction of the junior certificate programme has involved a series of in-service courses during school time which teachers of the programme are required to attend. In general, however, the in-service requirements of teachers at second level are catered for through the provision of courses outside of school hours in which teachers participate on a voluntary basis. I have no plans to change these arrangements.

In relation specifically to in-service training for primary teachers, this is one of the areas being examined by the Primary Education Review Body. I do not wish to pre-empt the findings of the review body in this regard by commenting further on the issues raised in the questions.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Second Level Teaching Year.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if, after account is taken of the time devoted to public examinations, the second level teaching year in Ireland at 164 days is substantially shorter than in any of the following countries: (a) Belgium (b) Denmark (c) West Germany (d) England (e) France (f) Italy (g) Luxembourg (h) the United States (i) the Netherlands and (j) Japan; and if this has any positive or adverse effect on the quality of Irish education.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: In Ireland second level schools may take credit for 12 public examination days towards the 180 days on which they are required to be in operation in the school year. From the information available to me, it would appear that the teaching year in Ireland is shorter than is the case for the countries mentioned. I am satisfied that the quality of education in Ireland stands comparison with that in other countries.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will include the educational data and descriptive material contained in the document Comprehensive Public Expenditure Programmes in future annual reports of her Department.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The document entitled Comprehensive Public Expenditure Programmes is not published on an annual basis. The full volume was published in 1986 and in 1988 but a summary volume only, entitled Summary of Public Expenditure Programmes was published in 1987 and is proposed for 1989. Consequently, the detailed educational data and descriptive material is not available on an annual basis for inclusion in my Department's annual Statistical Report. The annual Statistical Report already contains, in table 7 of section I, financial data corresponding generally to the summary information contained in the Summary of Public Expenditure Programmes and consideration is being given to the revision of this table to bring the data more in line with the current Department votes and with the public expenditure programme presentation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the annual capitation grant per pupil paid to national schools; the equivalent grant per pupil paid to all-Irish national schools; the higher costs which occur in all-Irish schools which justify the payment of a higher grant in their case; and if she favours the principle of payment of similar rates of capitation grants to all schools with equivalent running costs and equivalent autonomous local fund raising capacity.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The standard rate of capitation grant is £26.50 per pupil. The rate of capitation grant for all-Irish schools is £39.75 per pupil. The higher rate of grant paid to these schools applies because of their role in the promotion of the Irish language and is not directly related to the running costs of the all-Irish schools compared to other schools.

The financing of schools is one of the issues being examined by the Primary Education Review Committee. Our Programme for Government provided that efforts would be made to improve the level of funding for capitation grants in primary schools as resources become available.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Departmental Staff.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the number of staff employed in her Department (a) at present and (b) ten years ago in (i) the primary inspectorate and (ii) the post-primary inspectorate; and if she will outline the duties and responsibilities of the inspectorate in each case.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The numbers employed in the primary and post-primary inspectorates in 1979 and 1989 are:

MainHeading.P: The principal functions of the primary inspectorate are:
(a) to provide the Minister with the information and advice he/she may require on matters pertaining to individual schools and on educational matters in general;

(b) to co-operate with management authorities and teachers in the work of the schools, especially by stimulating interest in curriculum content and methodology and by assisting teachers in need of guidance.
In addition to the foregoing, the main responsibility of the post-primary inspectorate is the setting and marking of the certificate examinations.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she has obtained sanction in 1989 to transfer any moneys between subheads of the 1989 Estimates of her Department; and, if so, if she will give details thereof.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: In accordance with the general arrangements for the monitoring and control of public expenditure, my Department forwards detailed reports to the Department of Finance each month showing, in respect of the various subheads of the votes for which I am responsible, the allocation, the expenditure to date and the forecast of requirements each month to the end of the financial year. As the allocations are estimates which by their nature are imprecise, these reports frequently show projected outturns for individual subheads which are different from the allocation. Where necessary and appropriate, proposals for supplementary estimates are submitted to the Minister for Finance for introduction in the Dáil. Otherwise, the formal approval of the Minister for Finance is obtained under the virement arrangements. This formal approval is obtained after the end of the year when the Appropriation Accounts are being finalised. The Appropriation Accounts show for each subhead the amount of the Oireachtas grant, the actual expenditure and the difference. Where the difference exceeds 5 per cent, an explanatory note is appended to the account.
It is now intended to obtain sanction to transfer certain moneys between subheads of the 1989 Estimates of my Department.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the number of days of uncertified sick leave which secondary teachers may take without loss of pay; and the equivalent arrangements (a) for senior officials in her Department and (b) primary and vocational teachers.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The number of days of uncertified sick leave which may be taken, without loss of pay, is (a) Secondary teachers, ten school days in any quarter, only four of which may be taken consecutively; (b) Established civil servants, seven days in any 12 months, only two of which may be taken consecutively; (c) Primary teachers, 31 days in a calendar year, only three of which may be taken consecutively; (d) Vocational teachers: (permanent whole time), seven days in a year, only three of which may be taken consecutively.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the action taken on the recommendation of the Pupil Transfer Committee that a transfer adviser be appointed in every post-primary school.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The functions envisaged for advisers are discharged by year heads, tutors, staff engaged in pastoral care, career guidance teachers and, in some instances, holders of posts of responsibility.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the action taken on the recommendations of the Pupil Transfer Committee in respect of: (a) an in-service seminar for teachers involved with transfer problems and (b) inclusion of pupil transfer problems in teacher training syllabi.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The report of the Pupil Transfer Committee was submitted in May 1981 to the then Minister for Education. Following its publication, arrangements were made for account to be taken of relevant recommendations in the provision of pre-service and in-service training of teachers.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if any in-service courses have been designed to enable holders of posts of responsibility to play a constructive role in school administration as was announced in Paragraph 7.15 of The Programme for Action in Education; and the proportion of those holding such posts who have attended such courses.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: In-service courses of the type mentioned have been designed and conducted within the limits of available finance and in accordance with the White Paper on Educational Development (1980) along lines similar to those suggested by the Committee on In-service Education (1983).
Data on the proportion of those holding posts of responsibility who have attended such courses are not readily available in my Department.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Third Level Education Drop Out Rate.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the results of the study of the drop out rate of students from third level education announced in Paragraph 6.12 of The Programme for Action in Education; and if she will publish same.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: A preliminary study on this matter indicated that without detailed flow statistics the extent of uncertificated departure at third-level cannot be measured successfully. The feasibility of collecting appropriate flow data from third level institutions on a regular basis is being considered.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education, in regard to the technical and technological college sector, if action has been taken to reduce the number of staff student contact hours in order to allow for increased student numbers, without corresponding staff increases in accordance with Paragraph 6.13 of The Programme for Action in Education.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The number of wholetime students in the technical and technological colleges sector increased from 18,740 in the 1985-86 academic year to 23,265 in the 1988-89 academic year. During this period the teaching allocations to the colleges were not increased while the pay allocations were reduced by 1 per cent 3 per cent and 3 per cent in the years 1987, 1988 and 1989 respectively.

A committee established to examine third-level courses which lead to awards by the NCEA and other bodies outside the Universities examined in some detail the question of staff student contact hours. The committee's draft report has recently been circulated to interested parties for their views.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Third Level Sector Rationalisation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the number of courses which have been dropped or altered in higher education institutions, following upon the commitment in Paragraph 6.3 of The Programme for Action in Education to the effect that there should be rationalisation of courses and in some cases fundamental changes in programmes.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: Major improvements in productivity have occurred in the third-level sector as a result of rationalisation measures over the past few years. This is evidenced by the extent of the expansion which has taken place in the sector within the constraints of available resources.

As the range of courses on offer in the colleges constantly undergo changes for a variety of reasons, however, it would not be feasible to identify the particular courses which were altered or dropped specifically because of such rationalisation measures.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Link Colleges/Out Centre Courses.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the results of the examinations by the National Council for Education Awards of the feasibility of extending the system of providing courses in link colleges or out centres, that is, in existing centres outside of regional technical colleges, rather than increasing the range of courses in existing colleges or providing new colleges.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The results of the examination referred to by the Deputy are not yet available to me. I understand that the NCEA are currently formulating a report for my information.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Entry age to Higher Education.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she agrees with the opinion expressed in Paragraph 5.7 of The Programme for Action in Education by her predecessor, that many pupils are too young and too immature after five years in post-primary education for entry to higher education.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The degree of maturity achieved by pupils after five years in post-primary education can vary significantly. At post-primary level there are many options available to students to lengthen the school cycle. These are: (a) V.P.T.P., (b) Transition Year, (c) Repeat of a particular year within the guidelines or (d) Repeat of leaving certificate examination.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Computer Facilities in Post Primary Schools.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will outline the results of the programme of supplying micro-computer facilities to post primary schools; if these computers have been satisfactory; and if they have led to a very substantial increase in the awareness of computers by those participating in the educational system.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: Under the schemes of grant assistance for the provision of computer equipment in second-level schools, operated by my Department in 1981 and 1986, every second-level school in the State either received a new micro-computer system or else obtained enhancements to their existing facilities to bring them up to the level of a full system. These computers have operated satisfactorily and have had a positive impact on the education system by increasing awareness of computers among learners and teachers.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if any special provisions have been made in regard to the particular position of gifted children in our educational system.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The general principles of the primary school curriculum provide for the recognition of individual differences, and the provision of suitable learning experiences for children with special talents. In this connection my Department maintain liaison with An Óige Treithreach (the Association for Gifted Children), and in recent years the colleges of Education have taken a particular interest in this group, and weekend courses have been organised on an experimental basis in computer programmes for selected pupils. My Department's circular 16/73 on the responsibilities and duties of principal teachers and teachers in charge of national schools sets out that the principal teacher should ensure that additional opportunities and facilities are available to allow the most gifted pupils to make the fullest use of their natural abilities.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if any action has been taken on Paragraph 3.1 of the Programme for Action in Education in regard to re-examining whether a system of financing of schools based totally on enrolments can deal with the special circumstances arising in individual schools, notably schools which are developing or showing a decline in enrolment; and if any action has been taken pursuant to this re-examination.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: Consideration was given by a previous administration consultation with the patrons' representatives to the method of funding national schools in accordance with the commitment given in its Programme for Action in Education. It was generally agreed then that within existing resources it was not feasible to depart from the present system of capitation grants. The difficulties of certain schools are recognised and special additional grants have been made to the patrons of schools in Dublin, Cork and Limerick, so as to enable them to supplement the local contribution to schools which have been designated as serving disadvantaged areas.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will outline her present policy in regard to assigning extra assistants to schools for the purposes of helping class teachers to meet the remedial needs of children, the number of such special assistants who have been appointed; and the qualifications required for same.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: Providing for remedial needs of pupils in a class is part of the normal work of the class teacher. Where, in a school or group of schools, there is a substantial number of pupils with significant remedial needs, my Department are prepared to consider an application for approval of an additional post of remedial teacher. The number of such posts, which may be allocated at any particular time is subject to resourcing considerations. However, in accordance with the Programme for Government, my Department is currently considering what additional provision for approval of remedial teaching posts may be made at the present time.

At present, a total of 857 such posts have been approved in national schools. Remedial teachers are required to be qualified national teachers. No additional qualifications are prescribed but courses are conducted on an in-service basis for such teachers.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Waterford School Project Funding.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the reason for the delay in payment of moneys due to St. Paul's Parish, Lisduggan, County Waterford (details supplied) and what payment will be made.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: An instalment of grant in respect of professional fees for the national school project referred to by the Deputy was paid in October 1989. The school authorities have requested a higher grant and this is being considered in my Department. My Department will be in touch with the chairman of the board of management of the school in the matter at an early date.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will indicate the savings for the Exchequer, if any, that have arisen from the computerisation of examinations.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: There have been no direct financial savings to date as a result of the introduction of computerisation. The savings in 1989 are of an indirect nature. Because of the introduction of computerisation staff are free to complete other work in relation to examinations which they would otherwise be unable to do.
It is expected that there will be significant financial savings, particularly in relation to overtime costs, in the years ahead.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Proposed National Indoor Sports Stadium.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will give the up to date position regarding the acquisition of land and the possible date of start of construction of the proposed national indoor sports stadium.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The Custom House Docks Development Authority, who are acting as development agents for my Department on the National Sports Centre, will shortly have acquired approximately 50 per cent of the site. Negotiations are in train for the acquisition of the remainder of the site. It is not possible at this stage to give the possible date for the commencement of construction.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Small Primary Schools Improvement.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education her policy in regard to giving grants for the improvement of one, two and three teacher primary schools.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: Capital grants are made available to one and two teacher schools in the interest of keeping these school buildings serviceable and comfortable. Three teacher or larger schools are entitled under the rules for national schools to apply for capital grants in respect of a wide range of improvements. Subject to the advices of my Department's professional staff grants are sanctioned towards the cost of such improvements in the case of these schools.

asked the Minister for Education when work will be completed on the new premises at Gaelscoil Míde, Greendale Road, Kilbarrack, Dublin 5; and if it is intended to proceed with the erection of a palisade fencing at a matter of urgency, in view of the incidence of vandalism at the school.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The improvement works for Gaelscoil Míde, Greendale Road, Kilbarrack, Dublin 5 have been completed except for a number of minor items.

My Department has intended to provide palisade fencing around the whole complex but Dublin Corporation has stipulated that this should only be done as a last resort and other security measures should be considered.
This is being examined urgently by my Department and a decision will be conveyed to the school authorities at the earliest possible date.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Educational Courses for Unemployed.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the assistance which is available to persons over 26 who are unemployed and who wish to do full-time day courses in the vocational education committee colleges, to upgrade their educational qualifications; if her Department will pay the fees and book costs for people in this situation; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: At present the long-term unemployed can attend second-level courses under the vocational training opportunities scheme free of charge while getting an allowance equal to their entitlement to social welfare payments.
I have lately extended provision for this scheme to a further ten centres and plan to extend its availability progressively on a country-wide base.

MainHeading.P: It is open to unemployed persons over 26 who wish to attend a third-level course to apply for financial support under the higher education grants scheme and the VEC scholarship scheme. They may also qualify for support from the ESF funds depending on the course they wish to follow. There is no specific scheme available which provides for meeting the costs of books.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - National Lottery Fund Allocations.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the number of applications currently with her Department for allocations from the national lottery funds; and when a decision will be made on these applications.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The compilation of the information requested by the Deputy would involve an inordinate amount of time and I consider that the diversion of staff for this purpose from other work would not be warranted. Should the Deputy wish to inquire about a particular application I will endeavour to supply the information sought.

Applications under the recreational facilities scheme will now fall to be considered under the new arrangements for the recreational facilities/amenity grants scheme referred to by the Minister for Finance in his reply of 24 October 1989, to Questions Nos. 26, 48 and 55.

asked the Minister for Education having regard to Parliamentary Question No. 114 of 10 November, 1988 and the reply thereto, the way in which a person (details supplied) in County Kildare fails to meet the academic qualification criteria laid down in respect of applicants for teaching posts with various vocational educational committees; if she accepts that this person was previously capable of attaining temporary posts through the Vocational Education Committee; whether temporary posts require the same academic qualification as permanent posts; if not the way in which they differ; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

asked the Minister for Education if her attention has been drawn to the fact that moneys are due to a temporary vocational education committee appointed teacher (details supplied) in County Kildare; that these moneys are due in respect of work undertaken in years previous to the current year; the total amount of moneys due to this person; when payment will be made in this case; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 376 and 377 together.
The qualification required for appointment to permanent whole-time teaching posts under a Vocational Education Committee as set out in Memorandum V.7 are
`the degree of a recognised degree-awarding authority or an equivalent qualification acceptable to the Minister and the Ceard Teastas Gaeilge or an equivalent qualification in Irish'.
Normally, my Department requires the same qualifications for appointment to temporary whole-time teaching posts.

A proposal for the appointment of a temporary whole-time teaching post under a VEC of a person who lacks an acceptable qualification in Irish but who otherwise possesses an acceptable basic qualification may occasionally, as an exceptional matter, be sanctioned by my Department subject to the strict understanding that no fully qualified candidate is available.

In the case of the particular person to whom the Deputy refers, my Department is not in a position to carry out an assessment of the person's basic qualification as specific information which I have requested on several occasions has not been supplied to my Department.
The question of the payment of remuneration to vocational teachers is a matter solely for the appropriate Vocational Education Committee.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Occupational Travellers' Children's Education.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will give her response to the submission of the Irish Women's Guild to her on the education of the children of travelling persons in circuses and fun fairs.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I take it the Deputy is referring to the request for a meeting from the Irish Showmens' Guild which was made in the context of the forthcoming European Congress on “The occupational travellers: Rights to a decent education”.
My Department will be in contact with the guild shortly to arrange a meeting.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Leaving and Intermediate Certificates.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if her attention has been drawn to the discrepancies in the marking of various leaving and intermediate certificate papers; the reviews, if any, her Department have undertaken to rectify the matter; if she will introduce changes; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The National Council for Curriculum and Assessment has at my request set up a committee representative of interested parties to review the pattern of grades awarded on a subject by subject basis and to make recommendations on this matter for the future. I am awaiting the committee's report.
asked the Minister for Tourism and Transport if he will make a statement on the shortage of air traffic controllers which is causing undue delays and difficulties for air travellers at present.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan)
Speaker.P: Twenty seven staff, who are to be employed in the Air Traffic Control Service, are being recruited at present. Proposals for the recruitment of additional staff are among the matters being considered as part of a mediation process between my Department and representatives of the Air Traffic Control staff. The mediation is taking place under the Chairmanship of Mr. Tom McGrath, deputy chairman of the Labour Court. Pending the outcome of the mediation process, I do not wish to comment further at this stage.

asked the Minister for Tourism and Transport if he will arrange for the immediate issuing of a road haulier's licence to a person (details supplied) in County Tipperary whose application is with his Department since 27 June 1989 and which is required urgently for the running of his business.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan)
Speaker.P: I am happy to inform the Deputy that the licence in question was issued on 6 November 1989.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Leixlip (Kildare) Proposed Railway Station.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Tourism and Transport whether he intends sufficient money to be made available to Iarnród Éireann to enable that body to undertake the opening of the promised railway station at Confey, Leixlip, County Kildare; if his attention has been drawn to the urgent need for the provision of this facility in the area; to the fact that planning permission has already been granted in respect of this installation but that the matter has been shelved pending the availability of finance; whether he intends an allocation to be made for this work in the context of the 1990 Estimates; whether it is expected that funds will be allocated for this project from the EC Structural Funds soon to come on stream; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan)
Speaker.P: Approval was given in March of this year for Iarnród Éireann's proposal for upgrading the commuter service on the Dublin/Maynooth line. This would involve an expenditure of about £0.7 million for the opening of new stations at Confey, Coolmine, Castleknock and Broomebridge. The company were unable to proceed with the work this year because of the limited resources available to them and other priorities.

The funding of Iarnród Éireann's capital programmes is a matter for the company as capital grants are not given to the CIE group. The proposal has been included for assistance in the National Development Plan 1989-1993 and it is hoped that EC aid for the project will be forthcoming. Iarnród Éireann will be reviewing the proposal in the light of the outcome of the application for EC assistance and the CIE non-voted capital programme for 1990, which is determined in connection with the Estimates.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - National Lottery Fund Allocations.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Tourism and Transport the number of applications currently with his Department for allocations from national lottery funds; and when a decision will be made on these applications.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan)
Speaker.P: The only application which is being pursued by me in relation to 1990 concerns the funding of works by Iarnród Éireann to permit access to major rail stations by mobility handicapped persons. Decisions on applications for allocations from national lottery funds are a matter for the Government in due course.
